concept.title: What's new in version 1.1
concept.shortdesc: Learn about the main new functions in version 1.1.

dlentry.dd: You can use the Lightweight Third Party Authentication (LTPA) protocol to provide a single sign-on feature. This feature enables a client to authenticate only once in a domain name system to access resources on other servers that support the LTPA protocol. For example, servers such as , and . For more information about LTPA support in , see .

The dashboard now shows an overview of system connections and system performance. Statistics include the number of accepted and rejected messages, active connections, message throughput, the appliance uptime, and the appliance disk and memory usage. The dashboard can be viewed from the Home tab of the .
You can also view this information by using the command line command imaserver stat Server.

The resource adapter enables direct connection from to . This simplified Java Platform, Enterprise Edition architecture supports faster configuration, easier monitoring, and easier scaling of Java Platform, Enterprise Edition solutions to grow your enterprise. For more information, see IBM MessageSight resource adapter.

Durable and non-durable topic subscriptions can now be configured to be shared. In an unshared subscription, each subscriber to a particular topic receives a copy of every message that is published to that topic. In a shared subscription, each message is delivered to only one of the subscribers to that topic. There are a number of advantages to using shared subscriptions. For example, you can handle larger volumes of messages more efficiently by using multiple subscribers. Shared subscriptions also allow load balancing in an application server cluster.

dlentry.dt: Client certificate identity authentication and authorization
dlentry.dd: The common name that is contained in a client certificate can be used in connection and messaging policies to restrict access to . For example, if a device has a certificate that is burned in at the factory, you can use the unique common name in the certificate to ensure that only certain devices can connect, or can perform particular messaging actions. For more information, see .
